p:
We wanted to explore whether the increased parenchymal accumulation of soluble or cell-free αSyn, as well as intracellular inclusion pathology, could be due to impaired autophagic clearance in the seeded M83+/− mice. Because of previously reported data that IL-10 can inhibit autophagy
28, 29 , we reasoned that this might explain mechanistically the effect of Il-10-mediated worsening of αSyn proteinopathy. Using p62 as a marker of autophagic dysfunction
30 , we observed that αSyn seeding induced modest p62 accumulation in the spinal cords of GFP and Il-10-expressing mice (Fig. 7a–d) and the midbrain (Fig. 7e, f) compared to non-seeded genotype-matched and age-matched M83+/− mice. vIl-10, on the other hand, resulted in a profound upregulation of intracellular p62-immunoreactive inclusions in the thoracic and lumbar spinal cords (Fig. 7a–d; P < 0.001 relative to Il-10, P < 0.0001 relative to GFP) as well as in the midbrain (Fig. 7e, f; P < 0.05 relative to Il-10, P < 0.01 relative to GFP) of αSyn-seeded mice.
